history.content:
Hi OP! Sorry to hear about your midterm. If it helps at all, I was in the same boat as you last semester. I considered dropping it like you but ultimately I stuck with it. 

Personally, the hardest stuff was the pre-midterm 1 material (later parts of the course are more calculation heavy than proof heavy), but I think it's important to understand why you didn't do well on this midterm. Did you just freak out during the middle of the exam and lose your cool or did you not really understand the material? It might be worth it to schedule an appointment with Professor Rao to understand what went wrong.

Last semester when I talked to him, he took the time to go through several questions I missed and deconstruct my thought process for each question, which helped me realize I wasn't understanding the material as well as I thought I was. 

I did get a tutor and he helped a bit, but I'd say the most important thing for me was spending more time in office hours and doing homeworks. I also started reading the notes really thoroughly the day before lecture, so during lecture I would actually understand what was going on. (It's important to not get lost in the middle of lecture otherwise you're pretty screwed for the rest of the lecture).

Overall, it's not the end of the world, and midterm 1 is worth relatively little, especially if you're doing the homework option. 

For your reference, I got ~1 SD below on MT1 (roughly a C+ or B-), half a SD above on MT2, a full SD above on the final, and about a full SD above on most homeworks, and ended with an A-. Hopefully that helps! :)

children.subject: I would say it's possible but very hard. You should schedule an appointment with the TAs or Professor Rao to make sure though; usually TAs open one-on-one appointments right after the midterms.

good luck OP! <3

i am in a similar boat as you- i was wondering if anybody knows if i got about 2 SD below the mean, if it's still feasible to get an A-?

hello anon! i am planning to do this as this class has been incredibly difficult for me - do you have any advice on how your keeping up with the class went and how when you actually took 70 the next semester how that went also? and any advice maybe? thanks :)

I actually didn’t keep up with the class after dropping (perhaps a bad decision) but I downloaded all the notes and discussions and worked through all of them on my own time. My advice would be to pace yourself such that you don’t move on to the next note until you truly understand the note you are currently reading. It’s okay if it takes 3-4 days or more to absorb just one note. Retaking the class is still the same amount of work and effort but having seen the material before have me confidence which matters a lot in a class like 70.

I know this isn't possible for everybody but when this happened to me, I dropped the class and spent an entire semester self studying the material and taking time to truly understand the subject matter without the pressure of homework and exams. I then retook the class in the summer and did well, partially because I had effectively familiarized myself with the material and partially because I had changed my study habits (attended nearly all office hours, asked conceptual questions sooner than later, etc.) Best of luck!

Playing Devil's Advocate to Anon's Student Response:

While MT1 may be weighed less, Anon's suggestion implies that you perform much better on math concepts (Counting, probability, etc.) than proof, which may or may not be true.

history.content:
Should I keep my last cs-prereq-CS70 and not drop it even if I had a score that's one standard deviation lower than the grade I have to get, say I get the score for a B+ in midterm 1 but I need an A-?

What are your experiences on how midterm 1 scores correlate to the overall score?

I feel like I studied the hardest I've ever done for a class, but right before the midterm I just lost steam and it got really hard to focus. I had a plan to do a lot of practice midterms and review all the material, but I ended up feeling overwhelmed and not putting in the work. What's your advice for handling test anxiety and knowing when you've studied enough/coping with feeling like its never enough?

What do successful people do for CS70? Should I get a tutor?
history.subject: Midterm 1 Score C70 drop or not
